Indications and doses

Exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (if increased breathlessness interferes with daily activities),

By mouth

  • For adults
    30 mg daily for 7–14 days.

Severe croup (before transfer to hospital), Mild croup that might cause complications (before transfer to hospital),

By mouth

  • For children
    1–2 mg/kg.

Mild to moderate acute asthma (when oral corticosteroid taken for more than a few days), Severe or life-threatening acute asthma (when oral corticosteroid taken for more than a few days),

By mouth

  • For children 1 month–11 years
    2 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 60 mg) for up to 3 days, longer if necessary.

Mild to moderate acute asthma, Severe or life-threatening acute asthma,

By mouth

  • For adults
    40–50 mg daily for at least 5 days.
  • For children 1 month–11 years
    1–2 mg/kg once daily (max. per dose 40 mg) for up to 3 days, longer if necessary.
  • For children 12–17 years
    40–50 mg daily for at least 5 days.

Local treatment of inflammation (short-term),

To the eye

  • For adults
    Apply every 1–2 hours until controlled then reduce frequency.
  • For children
    Apply every 1–2 hours until controlled then reduce frequency.

Suppression of inflammatory and allergic disorders,

By intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    Initially 10–20 mg daily, dose preferably taken in the morning after breakfast, can often be reduced within a few days but may need to be continued for several weeks or months; maintenance 2.5–15 mg daily, higher doses may be needed; cushingoid side-effects increasingly likely with doses above 7.5 mg daily.
  • For adults
    25–100 mg 1–2 times a week, as prednisolone acetate.

Suppression of inflammatory and allergic disorders (initial dose in severe disease),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially up to 60 mg daily, dose preferably taken in the morning after breakfast, can often be reduced within a few days but may need to be continued for several weeks or months.

Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura,

By mouth

  • For adults
    1 mg/kg daily, gradually reduce dose over several weeks.

Eczematous inflammation in otitis externa,

To the ear

  • For adults
    Apply 2–3 drops every 2–3 hours, frequency to be reduced when relief obtained.
  • For children
    Apply 2–3 drops every 2–3 hours, frequency to be reduced when relief obtained.

Ulcerative colitis, Crohn’s disease,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 20–40 mg daily until remission occurs, followed by reducing doses, up to 60 mg daily, may be used in some cases, doses preferably taken in the morning after breakfast.

Neuritic pain or weakness heralding rapid onset of permanent nerve damage (during reversal reactions multibacillary leprosy),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 40–60 mg daily, dose to be instituted at once.

Generalised myasthenia gravis (when given on alternate days),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 10 mg once daily on alternate days, then increased in steps of 10 mg once daily on alternate days, increased to 1–1.5 mg/kg once daily on alternate days (max. per dose 100 mg).

Generalised myasthenia gravis in ventilated patients (when given on alternate days),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 1.5 mg/kg once daily on alternate days (max. per dose 100 mg).

Generalised myasthenia gravis (when giving daily),

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 5 mg daily, increased in steps of 5 mg daily. maintenance 60–80 mg daily, alternatively maintenance 0.75–1 mg/kg daily, ventilated patients may be started on 1.5 mg/kg (max. 100 mg) on alternate days.

Ocular myasthenia,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Usual dose 10–40 mg once daily on alternate days, reduce to minimum effective dose.

Reduction in rate of joint destruction in moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis of less than 2 years’ duration,

By mouth

  • For adults
    7.5 mg daily.

Polymyalgia rheumatica,

By mouth

  • For adults
    10–15 mg daily until remission of disease activity; maintenance 7.5–10 mg daily, reduce gradually to maintenance dose. Many patients require treatment for at least 2 years and in some patients it may be necessary to continue long term low-dose corticosteroid treatment.

Giant cell (temporal) arteritis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    40–60 mg daily until remission of disease activity, the higher dose being used if visual symptoms occur; maintenance 7.5–10 mg daily, reduce gradually to maintenance dose. Many patients require treatment for at least 2 years and in some patients it may be necessary to continue long term low-dose corticosteroid treatment.

Polyarteritis nodosa, Polymyositis, Systemic lupus erythematosus,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Initially 60 mg daily, then maintenance 10–15 mg daily.

Anorexia (symptom control in palliative care),

By mouth

  • For adults
    15–30 mg daily.

Pneumocystis pneumonia in moderate to severe infections associated with HIV infection,

By mouth

  • For adults
    50–80 mg daily for 5 days, the dose is then reduced to complete 21 days of treatment, corticosteroid treatment should ideally be started at the same time as the anti-pneumocystis therapy and certainly no later than 24–72 hours afterwards. The corticosteroid should be withdrawn before anti-pneumocystis treatment is complete.

Short-term prophylaxis of episodic cluster headache as monotherapy or in combination with verapamil during verapamil titration,

By mouth

  • For adults
    60–100 mg once daily for 2–5 days, then reduced in steps of 10 mg every 2–3 days until prednisolone is discontinued.

Proctitis,

By rectum using suppositories

  • For adults
    1 metered application 1–2 times a day for 2 weeks, continued for further 2 weeks if good response, to be inserted into the rectum, 1 metered application contains 20 mg prednisolone.
  • For adults
    5 mg twice daily, to be inserted in to the rectum morning and night, after a bowel movement.

Distal ulcerative colitis,

By rectum using rectal foam

  • For adults
    1 metered application 1–2 times a day for 2 weeks, continued for further 2 weeks if good response, to be inserted into the rectum, 1 metered application contains 20 mg prednisolone.

Rectal complications of Crohn's disease,

By rectum using suppositories

  • For adults
    5 mg twice daily, to be inserted in to the rectum morning and night, after a bowel movement.

Rectal and rectosigmoidal ulcerative colitis, Rectal and rectosigmoidal Crohn's disease,

By rectum using enema

  • For adults
    20 mg daily for 2–4 weeks, continued if response good, to be used at bedtime.

Advice when patient is pregnant

As it crosses the placenta 88% of prednisolone is inactivated.

Contra indications

Known side effects

Specific side effects

notKnown: local sensitivity reactions, adrenal suppression following prolonged use in neonates in neonates, corneal thinning, scleral thinning,

Advice for patients and carers

Patient counselling is advised for prednisolone tablets (steroid card).

In children

Prednisolone (oral) for nephrotic syndome

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/prednisolone-oral-for-nephrotic-syndrome

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Prednisolone for asthma

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/prednisolone-for-asthma

Cautions regarding administration

  • When used by ear: avoid prolonged use
  • With rectal use: systemic absorption may occur with rectal preparations
  • With systemic use: Duchenne’s muscular dystrophy (possible transient rhabdomyolysis and myoglobinuria following strenuous physical activity)

Unlicensed use

When used by eye in children

Pred Forte not licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturer).

With rectal use in children

Prednisolone rectal foam not licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturer).

When used by ear in children

Licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturers).

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

When used by eye

Although multi-dose prednisolone eye drops commonly contain preservatives, preservative-free unit dose vials may be available.

Prepared medicinal forms of PREDNISOLONE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: eye drops, oral suspension, ear drops, oral solution, enema,
